title: Ushabti of King Taharqa
description:
Large alabaster ushabti of Tirhaqa (688-663 BC). The figure is made of an extremely beautiful alabaster which appears different form that usually found in Egypt, the veining being much less pronounced. The figure is of exactly the same type as 39.2.
Condition: Workmanship excellent. There are several deposits and stains on the back apparently caused by water.

museum_location.name: This item is not on view

completeness.name: Best
completeness.description: All data has been vetted. Objects generally have quality photos and descriptions.

labels.content: Taharqa was one of the rulers of the Nubian Kingdom of Napata who also ruled Egypt in the Twenty-fifth Dynasty (circa 760–656 c.e.). Having conquered Egypt, the Nubian royal family adopted many Egyptian customs. Shabtis are funerary figures intended to do the agricultural work the gods might require of the deceased.

collections.name: Egyptian, Classical, Ancient Near Eastern Art

exhibitions.title: Africa in Antiquity: The Arts of Ancient Nubia and the Sudan
